title: Planned Parenthood to Expand App-Based Health Services to All 50 States
text:
WASHINGTON—Planned Parenthood Federation of America will expand a telemedicine program to connect patients with birth-control and other services via smartphone, part of the organization’s effort to extend the reach of its health-care offerings that Republican policy makers have sought to weaken or destroy.

Planned Parenthood’s telemedicine app will be available in all 50 states by next year, up from 27 states and Washington, D.C., currently, officials said Wednesday.

The app, called Planned Parenthood Direct, lets patients use a smartphone to request birth control delivered to their door, obtain prescription treatment for urinary-tract infections or make an appointment at a Planned Parenthood clinic. The goal is partly to reach younger generations more familiar with mobile technology, as well as women in rural areas who may lack easy access to in-person services, the nonprofit organization said.

Expanding the app represents Planned Parenthood’s latest move to blunt efforts by the Republican-led states and the Trump administration to cut the organization’s funding.

“As politicians across the country try to restrict or block access to critical reproductive and sexual health care, the Planned Parenthood Direct app is just one part of the work we do to ensure that more people can get the care they need, no matter where they are,” said Alexis McGill Johnson, acting president and chief executive of Planned Parenthood.

Last month, the organization opted to forgo about $60 million in annual federal funds rather than adhere to new Trump administration restrictions on its ability to refer patients for abortion.

States have sought to strip Medicaid funding from Planned Parenthood, efforts it has fought in the courts. The Trump administration has also tried to steer funding for teen-pregnancy-prevention programs to organizations that promote abstinence, many of which are religiously affiliated. Abortion-rights groups including Planned Parenthood have challenged such moves as unconstitutional restrictions on abortion access guaranteed by the Supreme Court’s 1973 Roe v. Wade decision.

Some Planned Parenthood affiliates use telemedicine to offer abortion services, in which a provider prescribes mifepristone and misoprostol to end early pregnancies, but they still require in-person visits to an office.

Planned Parenthood currently offers abortion medication through a telemedicine model in 14 states. About 20 states ban providers from using online technology to provide the medications that induce an early abortion.

Corrections & Amplifications

Planned Parenthood’s telemedicine app is currently available in 27 states and Washington, D.C. An earlier version of this article incorrectly stated it was available in 26 states and Washington, D.C. (Sept. 4, 2019)

description: Planned Parenthood will expand a telemedicine program to connect patients with birth-control and other services via smartphone as the organization seeks to counter Republican efforts to weaken its health-care offerings.
